Bybee, Perkins, and Pagliuca (1994) argue that the realis/irrealisdistinction “is not cross-linguistically valid” (p. 238); however Chafe (1995) andMithun (1995) have both taken the position that the distinction between realis andirrealis is arguably valid, and that the term ‘irrealis’ is descriptively useful. Eventhough the application of the term ‘irrealis’ varies from language to language (orauthor to author), nevertheless, there are certain constructions which tend to getlabeled irrealis over and over again. Chafe lists the following contexts in which alanguage might employ the irrealis mood: yes-no questions, negations, futures,necessities (or obligations), possibilities, imperatives, prohibitions, and conditions(p. 350, 362).
